awd_titl_txt: Exploring ways to use national datasets to promote broader participation of race-gender groups in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. This project will conduct an early stage exploratory study of an untested idea that will address the nation's STEM workforce needs. It will use a radically different approach to uncover barriers that impede broader participation by specific race-gender groups in STEM fields. The study will investigate whether school policies and practices regarding safety, discipline, school crime, suspensions and other such related factors, within charter and traditional public schools, contribute to the loss of large numbers of underrepresented students from the STEM pipeline. This is especially important since decades of efforts have not resulted in a stronger and more diverse 21st Century STEM workforce. To help address this condition, this study will examine the interplay of three main areas often cited as reasons the nation's human resource needs remain unmet. The study will focus on the impact of policies and practices on the STEM outcomes of race-gender groups. It will also look at how these schools differ in their mediation of the relationship of these regulations with STEM outcomes. Finally, the study will examine the impact school location and student residency have on strategies employed. There are currently no studies that have explored this approach. This study will attempt to lead the field in that regard.

Through an interdisciplinary approach, student data from the National Center for Education Statistics will be merged and analyzed. With no prior efforts to guide these mergers, this novel approach is risky since it remains unknown if any viable solutions will emerge to address barriers to meeting future STEM workforce needs. Yet, the potential payoff will be significant if results show that such work is not only feasible, but capable of contributing to foundational knowledge that links school policies and practices to broadening participation in STEM. The main outcome of this work will be a longitudinal dataset of 9th graders and will contain measures of their exposure to specific barriers, type of charter or traditional public school previously attended, and residential locations. The dataset will also relate specific contextual factors to outcomes in algebra and science concepts, math and science identity, and STEM degree aspirations. Thus, the study will advance knowledge about theories of social control and intersectionality. The policy relevance of this research will also be significant and may generate knowledge about the human capital cost of policies and practices; and potentially transformative alternatives that, if adopted, could redirect students' pathways into STEM fields instead of out of the pipeline. Further, outcomes from the study will also be available for widespread use by STEM educators, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students and researchers at other institutions who may generate future research beneficial to society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This EAGER award "Exploring ways to use national datasets to promote broader participation of race-gender groups in STEM" leveraged federal national databases to understand whether social control in the form of school suspensions were related to a number of important student outcomes, including math test scores, math self-efficacy, and college entry, among others. Since those race-gender groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM pipeline are also overrepresented in the school-to-prison pipeline, understanding the impact of discipline on STEM is among the most important social issues facing this country. With just two years of funding, this project generated five published articles in high impact scientific journals, one book chapter, one dissertation, eight presentations at scientific conferences, and supported one postdoctoral research fellow and a doctoral student who went on to defend his dissertation and become an assistant professor at Washington University in St. Louis. 

The interrelatedness of the school-to-prison and STEM pipelines established within this study is this project?s intellectual merit. This was accomplished in a number of ways. First, suspensions lowered student math test scores, their likelihood of attending college, and increased dropout rates, especially for African American students. Second, this work showed schools that ranked in the top third in their use of suspensions had lowered math test outcomes and rates of college entry for their students in comparison to those schools that ranked in the lowest third in suspension use. These troubling outcomes persisted when individual suspensions were taken into account, suggesting that the average math outcomes and rates of college entry were significantly lower for students regardless if they had directly received a suspension or not. These differences between high and low suspension schools were large. For example, the likelihood that students would enter college was 14 percentage points lower for those enrolled in schools that relied on suspensions most heavily in comparison to students in schools that relied on suspensions least. This project relied on advanced quantitative and data science methods to equalize the distribution of students and their backgrounds between the two school types, and then took into consideration the schools? average levels of disorder and other neighborhood, school, and social background factors.

Third, this work also generated knowledge about racial disparities in discipline and STEM. This new knowledge established that students of color, and specifically Black students, were more likely to be enrolled in schools that issued the most suspensions. Therefore, they were more likely to be suspended and incur setbacks to their math test scores and chances of college attendance. It also found that predominantly Black schools had more prominent school-to-prison pipelines but also prominent STEM pipelines. We explored this finding further in another study to understand how both could exist within schools. Our results showed that African Americans who were suspended had math test scores no different than those African Americans who were not suspended within majority Black schools. However, the math performances of Black students who had been suspended declined as the percentage of white students in their schools increased until they were significantly lower than Black students who had not been suspended, suggested that the school-to-prison and STEM pipelines are most inversely related within racially heterogeneous schools.

In sum, the findings of this project emphasize that filling the STEM pipeline will require schools to first drain the school to prison pipeline because the nation is wasting its future mathematics potential through strict discipline. The broader impacts of the project will be significant if the results of its studies are used to inform school discipline reform, especially for minoritized students.
